repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Minas Gerais Development
            Partnership Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Minas Gerais Development
            Partnership Project received a satisfactory development
            outcome with moderate risk to development outcome. The Bank
            received a satisfactory rating for their performance while
            the Borrower received a highly satisfactory performance
            rating. There were several restructuring this project went
            through, five in total. The result of each restructuring was
            an extension of the closing date. The first restructuring
            was to address a financing gap arising from unanticipated
            circumstances, and to scale up project activities. The
            second procurement was due to delays in procurement
            processes required an extension of the closing date to allow
            for the full disbursement of the technical assistance
            component. The third restructuring provided an extension to
            allow for the implementation of two consultancies (a
            feasibility study on a train network and an Economic Master
            Plan for the Belo Horizonte metropolitan area) in the
            technical assistance component. The fourth restructuring
            extended to closing date to be able to use remaining funds
            under the TA component to extend the scope of the Economic
            Master Plan consultancy by including 14 additional
            municipalities in the study. The final restructuring
            extended to closing date due to delays in approving the
            procurement of the last contract (Economic Master Plan
            consultancy). Several lessons were taken from this project
            including the following: (1) the importance of a technical
            assistance component to foster innovation, (2) the
            value-added through technical assistance provided by the
            Bank, (3) the importance of technical assistance as a
            vehicle for continued dialogue, (4) disbursement-linked
            indicators as a performance push, (5) attention needs to be
            given to the design of the DLIs, and (6) the financing of
            eligible expenditure programs (EEPs) can serve to protect
            certain categories of spending in certain sectors.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Minas Gerais Development
            Partnership Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objectives of the Second
            Minas Gerais Development Partnership Project for Brazil are
            to: (i) to help the State of Minas Gerais improve the
            efficiency and effectiveness of public resource use and
            allocation for economic and social development; (ii) to
            support the adoption of innovations in public management by
            the State; and (iii) to support the state in strengthening
            its results-based management system of monitoring and
            evaluation of results. The extension is necessary for the
            project to be fully and successfully completed. Additional
            time is needed to complete technical assistance activities
            of strategic importance to the borrower, related to the new
            institutional arrangements introduced for the management of
            the Metropolitan Region of Belo Horizonte (MRBH), the state
            capital. The activities seek to support the development of
            master plans to guide urban and economic development in key
            areas of the metropolitan region. This initiative could have
            potential demonstration effects for other metropolitan areas
            in Brazil. The contract with the consulting company was
            signed in early December 2012.This will be the third
            extension of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Minas Gerais Development
            Partnership Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objectives of the Second
            Minas Gerais Development Partnership Project for Brazil are
            to: (i) to help the State of Minas Gerais improve the
            efficiency and effectiveness of public resource use and
            allocation for economic and social development; (ii) to
            support the adoption of innovations in public management by
            the State; and (iii) to support the State in strengthening
            its results-based management system of monitoring and
            evaluation of results. The closing date for the project will
            be extended from March 31st, 2012 until October 31st, 2013.
            This will be the first extension of the project after the
            approval of the additional financing by the Board. The
            extension of nineteen months, from March 31st, 2012 till
            October 31st, 2013, is consistent with the OP13.20
            requirement that the additional loan closes within three
            years of the closing date of the original loan that is in
            effect when the additional loan is approved, which is March
            31, 2012 given that a restructuring and extension of the
            original loan was approved by the Board simultaneously with
            the approval of the additional financing. As confirmed with
            LCSDE, since the extension is below twenty four months from
            the current project closing date, as approved by the Board
            at the time of the approval of the additional financing. The
            project is in the final stages of implementation and has
            been making satisfactory progress towards the achievement of
            its development objectives. The project implementation is
            also rated satisfactory. Disbursements to date account to
            US$1.426 billion; which corresponds to 99.2 percent of total
            Bank financing (US$1.437 billion).
